Subject: Re: [neat] Batching the population on GPU?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=Lm7QjNMctRG1DDy2qfFOL4D1PTJE2-wloqdG6-67TeeO9sc4Q6jF
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Hi  Stefano,

> The issue is that in NE we have many relatively small matrices
> whereas with traditional ML methods we have few very large matrices.
> The latter are trivially easy to take advantage of with GPU hardware.

Traditional NEAT could be viewed as evolving one large sparse matrix,
i.e. imagine one large matrix with all of the node IDs across the top,
and again down the side. All of the main math libraries with matrix
optimizations have support for sparse matrices and a handful of
standard compressed formats, CSR being the main format:

    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparse_matrix#Compressed_sparse_row_.28CSR.2C_CRS_or_Yale_format.29

E.g. CUDA has support, as does Intel MKL, ATLAS, OpenBLAS, etc. E.g.:

    https://developer.nvidia.com/cusparse
    https://software.intel.com/en-us/node/471374

However, the performance compared to dense matrices is far less in
terms of number of connections handled per sec, because fundamentally
the data is no longer in contiguous chunks that can be loaded,
operated on, and stored, in efficient hardware vector operations. But
there is still a boost to be had, especially on GPUs where you have
lots of parallel compute units as well as vector instructions.

It may also be possible to analyse the connectivity graph to assign a
layer number to each node, and then use one matrix between each pair
of layers that are connected, because in NEAT we have no restriction
on which nodes are connected to each other (e.g. layer 1 connecting
directly to layer 10, or in even layer 10 connecting to layer 1 (as an
aside, in sharpneat I define depth in cyclic nets as the minimum
number of hops to get to a node from the input layer). The idea/hope
being that each intra-layer matrix would be dense enough that we could
use dense matrix format with zero weights for the absent connections.
However, unless they are reasonably dense then this won't outperform a
single large sparse matrix.

We could also conceive of modifying NEAT so that it evolved structure
more conducive to the optimizations that are available, so e.g.
evolving actual layers where connectivity is strictly enforced to be
between adjacent layers. My hunch is that there may be merit to this
approach.

In HyerNEAT we get to define the substrate by hand, so the networks
tend to be more regular and dense, so I believe dense matrices could
be a big boost in running the final networks, but not CPPNs because
they have the above discussed problems - since CPPNs are essentially
NEAT but with the added problem of allowing different activation
functions per node (maybe I should call that heterogeneous node
activation functions).

I'm working towards experimenting with some of the above ideas, but my
current focus is on a large scale code re-organisation so I'm not
working on these ideas right now.

While I'm here - where can I find a high level description of your K^2 graphs?

Colin
